docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 2 NOTICE TO PRODUCE BEFORE HEARING [rr 21.9–21.13]

heading.title: PART 21 DISCOVERY, INSPECTION AND NOTICE TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTS [rr 21.1–21.13]
DIVISION 2 NOTICE TO PRODUCE BEFORE HEARING [rr 21.9–21.13]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 21 DISCOVERY, INSPECTION AND NOTICE TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTS [rr 21.1–21.13]
DIVISION 2 NOTICE TO PRODUCE BEFORE HEARING [rr 21.9–21.13]

p.text: In this Division:
means a notice to produce referred to in rule 21.10 .
means a party to whom another party is producing, or being asked to produce, documents or things for inspection.
means a party who is producing, or being asked to produce, documents or things for inspection.

For the purposes of this Division, a document or thing is to be taken to be relevant to a fact in issue if it could, or contains material that could, rationally affect the assessment of the probability of the existence of that fact (otherwise than by relating solely to the credibility of a witness), regardless of whether the document or thing would be admissible in evidence.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 21.10] r 21.10 Notice to produce for inspection by parties (cf SCR Part 23, rule 2(1); DCR Part 22, rule 2(1), (1A) and (2))

leg:heading.title: Notice to produce for inspection by parties (cf SCR Part 23, rule 2(1); DCR Part 22, rule 2(1), (1A) and (2))

p.text: Party A may, by notice served on party B, require party B to produce for inspection by party A:
any document or thing that is referred to in any originating process, pleading, affidavit or witness statement filed or served by party B, and
any other specific document or thing that is clearly identified in the notice and is relevant to a fact in issue.
A notice to produce may specify a time for production of all or any of the documents or things required to be produced.
The approved form is Form 19 : Notice to Produce for Inspection.

level.toc-caption: [21.10.10] Documents referred to in originating process, pleadings, affidavits or statements

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.10.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56(1), (2), s 68.

heading.title: Documents referred to in originating process, pleadings, affidavits or statements

p.text: The present rule, read with CPA s 68 and UCPR r 21.11 , requires a party to comply with any notice to produce a document that has been “referred to” in an originating process, pleading, affidavit or witness statement. A party must also comply with a notice to produce any other document, that (i) has been “clearly identified” in the notice to produce and (ii) is shown to be “relevant to a fact in issue”.

The concept of relevance to a fact in issue is discussed in [21.1.10] . It operates as a limit on the permissible scope of discovery (see UCPR r 21.2(4) ) and the proper scope of the subpoena power (see [33.4.30] ), as well as the production obligation imposed by UCPR r 21.10(1)(b) . While there is no explicit similar restriction in the case of UCPR r 21.10(1)(a) , the rule implicitly assumes the likely relevance of a document that has been “referred to” in either a pleading, affidavit or other document to which the rule applies: Quilter v Heatley (1883) 23 Ch D 42 . Where the relevance of such a document is controversial, it is for the party resisting production to satisfy the court that production is not required: Jefferson Ford Pty Ltd v Ford Motor Co of Aust [2007] VSC 450; BC200709899 at [30]–[35] . If the court is satisfied that a document has no apparent relevance to a fact in issue, it may dispense with production in response to the notice: UCPR r 21.11 .

Under other rules a “pleading” has been held to include particulars: Cass v Fitzgerald [1884] WN 18; Milbank v Milbank [1900] 1 Ch 376 at 385 ; but unless the particulars are actually contained in a pleading it is difficult to reconcile that view with the definition in the Dictionary. The reference to “affidavits” has been held to include exhibits to affidavits: Re Hinchcliffe [1895] 1 Ch 117 ; verified answers to interrogatories: Moore v Peachey [1891] 2 QB 707 ; affidavits verifying particular discovery: Pardy’s Mozambique Syndicate v Alexander [1903] 1 Ch 191 .

UCPR r 21.10(1)(a) and 21.10(1)(b) appear to differ markedly in the degree of precision required about the identification of any particular document. In particular UCPR r 21.10(1)(a) operates if the document is “referred to” in a relevant document. It explicitly does not require that the document whose production is sought must be “clearly identified” (UCPR r 21.10(1)(b) ) or “identified” (UCPR r 33.4(4)(a) ) or “specified” (UCPR r 34.1(1) ). Consequently, a document may be sufficiently “referred to” if it is merely described or referred to in a general manner: Smith v Harris (1883) 48 LT 869 ; or as part of an identified class of documents: Dubai Bank Ltd v Galadari (No 2) [1990] 2 All ER 738; [1990] 1 WLR 731 at 738–9 . However, the relevant reference must involve a direct allusion to the document itself, as distinct from its effect or the information it contains: New Cap Reinsurance Corporation Ltd (in liq) v Daya [2008] NSWSC 763; BC200806775 at [36] ff; Welker v Rinehart [2012] NSWSC 588; BC201203727 (relevant paragraphs of notice to produce set aside — no direct allusion to document, only indirect reference to material that may exist).
The requirement for a “direct allusion”, and the difference between a document and the information it contains, can lead to nice distinctions being drawn. This can be illustrated by various examples:

a statement that a transaction has been effected is not a reference to the documents recording the transaction: Dubai Bank Ltd v Galadari (No 2) [1990] 2 All ER 738; [1990] 1 WLR 731 at 738–9 (reference to “setting up a discretionary trust”);

a statement about the receipt of a letter is a reference to the letter: Quilter v Heatley (1883) 23 Ch D 42 ; Rubin v Expandable Ltd [2008] All ER (D) 148 (Feb); [2008] 1 WLR 1099; [2008] EWCA Civ 59 at [22] — reference to the fact that “a letter” had been received); Dubai Bank Ltd v Galadari (No 2) [1990] 2 All ER 738; [1990] 1 WLR 731 at 738–9 (reference to “a guarantee” and “a mandate from the account holders”);
a statement that a transaction was recorded in “books of account” is a reference to the relevant accounting entries: Quilter v Heatley (1883) 23 Ch D 42 ;
a statement that events were recorded in a diary is a reference to the diary: Jefferson Ford Pty Ltd v Ford Motor Co of Aust [2007] VSC 450; BC200709899 at [30]–[35];
a statement that a particular word has been used in particular kinds of documents is a reference to all of those documents: Smith v Harris (1883) 48 LT 869 ;

a statement disclosing the fact, or the effect, of advice that has been received is not a reference to a document containing the advice: Welker v Rinehart [2012] NSWSC 599 (reference to “legal and financial advice” not a direct allusion to a document); King v GIO Australia Holdings Ltd [2001] FCA 1487; BC200106482 at [18] (accounting advice — statement that forecast and budgets had been prepared — did not involve a reference to a document for the purposes of the notice to produce rule). New Cap Reinsurance Corporation Ltd (in liq) v Daya [2008] NSWSC 763; BC200806775 (legal advice) — but the disclosure of the substance or effect of information will waive any privilege that would otherwise apply: see [21.5.120] and [21.5.130] ;

a statement that reproduces information contained in a document may not involve a reference to the document itself: Rigg v Associated Newspapers [2003] EWHC 710 at [13]; but contrast Rubin v Expandable Ltd [2008] All ER (D) 148 (Feb); [2008] 1 WLR 1099; [2008] EWCA Civ 59 at [22] and [24].

It is perhaps questionable whether the nice distinctions involved in some of the earlier decisions reflect an approach to the interpretation of the rules that is entirely consistent with CPA s 56(1) and (2) : see, for example, Dubai Bank Ltd v Galadari (No 2) [1990] 2 All ER 738; [1990] 1 WLR 731 at 738H. The mere identification or description of a document, or a reference to it, neither necessarily waives any privilege that would otherwise apply, nor demonstrates the document’s relevance to a fact in issue. Furthermore, if the document is in fact relevant to a fact in issue, its production may be required either by discovery (see UCPR r 21.3 ) or subpoena. Accordingly, the view may properly be taken that parties should cooperate in making available for inspection any relevant, non-privileged document whose production has been requested by a notice to produce: Rubin v Expandable Ltd [2008] All ER (D) 148 (Feb); [2008] 1 WLR 1099; [2008] EWCA Civ 59 at [23]–[26] and [21.10.15] .
Legislation cited in [21.10.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.10, r 21.10(1)(a), r 21.3, r 33.3, 34.1.

The intention underlying r 21.10 is that a notice to produce under the rule is not to subject parties either to any kind of general discovery obligation or to substitute for a general subpoena. The expressions “document”, “specific document” and “clearly identified” in r 21.10(1)(a) and (b) are to be construed against this background. Accordingly, any notice given under that rule must identify the documents to which it refers with reasonable precision: Penrith Rugby League Club Ltd v Brown [2004] NSWSC 1182 ; BC200408601 at [8] per Young CJ in Eq (“there must be a pointing out in a manner that is distinct and free from confusion”); Kursell v Timber Operators & Contractors Ltd [1927] 1 KB 298 at 313–14 per Sargant LJ (the word “specific” conjures up the idea of something which is identified and not merely identifiable); Douglas Corporation Pty Ltd v Currico Nominees Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 113; BC200700860 at [29] per Harrison AJ (“references to documents require strict specificity in order to identify the individual document sought). As a general rule, a notice will not “clearly identify” documents, nor will it permit satisfaction that they are “relevant to a fact in issue”, if it merely identifies them by their relationship to a stated subject matter. The notice is especially unlikely to satisfy those requirements if the subject matter is itself stated broadly and without a disciplined temporal restriction: Norris v Kandiah [2007] NSWSC 1296; BC200709798 (notice to produce called for classes of documents relating to general and taxation correspondence over periods up to 7 years). However, much will depend upon the actual description given in the notice and the objective justification for requiring production of the documents in the particular circumstances. In applying the rules both the party requiring discovery and the party who receives a notice ought to apply reasonable judgment in assessing whether or not any particular notice to produce is in accordance with the rules. If in fact the notice is reasonably specific, and the documents to which it relates are obviously relevant to facts in issue, there is no practical utility in disputing the validity of the notice and forcing the party seeking production either to apply for an order under r 21.3 or issue a subpoena or further notice to produce — under UCPR r 33.3 or 34.1 . Owners Strata Plan SP 69567 v Baseline Constructions Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 502; BC201203158 at [9] (notice to produce under UCPR r 21.10 set aside; leave to serve notice under UCPR r 34.1 granted); Patonga Beach Holdings Pty Ltd v Lyons [2009] NSWSC 869; BC200907828 at [12] (limited notice under UCPR r 34.1 allowed after setting aside notice under UCPR r 21.10). See also [34.1.30].

level.toc-caption: [21.10.20] Relevant to a fact in issue

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.10.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.9(2).
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 55.

heading.title: Relevant to a fact in issue

p.text: A document is relevant to a fact in issue if its contents can rationally affect the assessment of the probability of the existence of that fact: see UCPR r 21.9(2) . This poses a similar test to that in Evidence Act 1995 s 55 , except that it excludes documents relating only to the credibility of a witness. The concept of “relevance” for the purposes of discovery under this Part must be applied to the contents of the document, rather than to the document itself. It therefore embraces not only documents that are admissible in evidence, but also documents whose contents would otherwise tend to advance either party’s case. (The concept of relevance to a fact in issue is discussed further at [21.1.10] .) Although the concept of relevance under the present rules is wide, it is narrower than the criterion that applied under the previous rules: National Australia Bank Ltd v Idoport Pty Ltd [2000] NSWCA 8; BC200000274 . It is more narrow because it does not require discovery of documents merely because they might reasonably be regarded as leading to a train of inquiry that might advance a party’s case: Mulley v Manifold (1959) 103 CLR 341; 33 ALJR 168; BC5900640 ; and see further [23.3.14] .

What is a fact in issue in proceedings is not determined exclusively by the pleadings. If a case is commenced by summons (and even if it is later continued on pleadings) the issues are identified by the relief claimed, the law that relates to that relief claimed and the affidavit or support evidence deployed in support of or against it. Those matters continue to be in issue until an allegation is abandoned by the plaintiff or admitted by the defendant: British American Tobacco Australia Ltd v Gordon [2006] NSWSC 1473; BC200611331 at [7]–[9] .
Legislation cited in [21.10.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 34.1.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 21.11] r 21.11 Production under notice to produce (cf SCR Part 23, rule 2(3) and (4); DCR Part 22, rule 2(3) and (4))

leg:heading.title: Production under notice to produce (cf SCR Part 23, rule 2(3) and (4); DCR Part 22, rule 2(3) and (4))

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, party B must, within a reasonable time after being served with a notice to produce:
produce for party A’s inspection such of the documents or things referred to in the notice (other than privileged documents) as are in party B’s possession, and
serve on party A, in respect of any document that is not produced, a notice stating:
that the document is a privileged document, or
that the document is, to the best of party B’s knowledge, information and belief, in the possession of a person identified in the notice, or
that party B has no knowledge, information or belief as to the existence or whereabouts of the document.
For the purposes of subrule (1):
unless party B establishes to the contrary, 14 days or longer after service of the notice is to be taken to be a reasonable time, and
unless party A establishes to the contrary, less than 14 days after service of the notice is to be taken to be less than a reasonable time.

The intention of Pt 21 is to confine discovery to those documents that are relevant to a fact in issue in the proceedings. Accordingly, the provisions of this rule concerning Notices to Produce substantially limit the chain of enquiry which is available: see Riley v Tower Life Australia Ltd (NSWSC, Harrison M, 8 October 1997, unreported, BC9705034).

The validity of a notice to produce depends upon whether reasonable time, rather than 14 days, has been allowed for production. A notice is not invalid either because it requires production sooner than 14 days, or because no abridgement of time has been obtained or because the time specified is unreasonable in relation to some of the documents sought: Bidald Consulting Pty Ltd (t/as Forstaff) v Miles Special Builders Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 977; BC200507546 ; Welker v Rinehart [2012] NSWSC 839; BC201205570 (requirement to produce a single document — time permitted of 2 days reasonable in the circumstances).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 21.12] r 21.12 Personal injury claims (cf SCR Part 23, rule 5, Part 24, rule 1(3); DCR Part 22, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Personal injury claims (cf SCR Part 23, rule 5, Part 24, rule 1(3); DCR Part 22, rule 5)

p.text: In any proceedings on a common law claim:
for damages arising out of the death of, or bodily injury to, any person, or
for contribution in respect of damages so arising,

a party is not required to comply with a notice to produce in relation to a document or thing that has not been referred to in any originating process, pleading, affidavit or witness statement filed or served by that party unless the court, for special reasons, orders otherwise.
Rule 21.8 provides a similar restriction against requiring discovery in personal injury proceedings. See the note to that rule.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 21.13] r 21.13 Costs and expenses of compliance (cf rule 33.11)

leg:heading.title: Costs and expenses of compliance (cf rule 33.11)

p.text: The court may order party A to pay the amount of any reasonable loss or expense incurred by party B in complying with a notice to produce.
If an order is made under subrule (1), the court must fix the amount or direct that it be fixed in accordance with the court’s usual procedure in relation to costs.
[r 21.13 insrt Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[4], effective 6 July 2007]

level.toc-caption: [21.13.5] Costs and expenses of compliance with notice of motion

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.13.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.33.

heading.title: Costs and expenses of compliance with notice of motion

p.text: The court has power to order a party to pay the costs and expenses of compliance with a notice to produce. (As to what may fall within the concept of “reasonable loss or expense” see [33.11.5] .) The parties must attempt to agree on the amount of costs and expenses that are payable for compliance before seeking an order for the payment of those costs and expenses: see UCPR r 42.33 .
